title: James Shuler
text:
James Shuler (May 29, 1959 – March 17, 1986) was a U.S. Olympic and professional <a href="Boxing">boxer</a> from <a href="Philadelphia">Philadelphia</a> known as "Black Gold."
Amateur career.
Shuler was trained by <a href="Joe%20Frazier">Joe Frazier</a>.
Shuler was the 1979 and 1980 National Golden Gloves Light Middleweight Champion. He qualified at 156 pounds and was a member of the <a href="1980%20U.S.%20Olympic%20boxing%20team">1980 U.S. Olympic boxing team</a> that perished in <a href="LOT%20flight%20007">an air crash</a> in <a href="Warsaw">Warsaw</a>, <a href="Poland">Poland</a>, on March 14, 1980 <a href="http%3A//www.astm.org/cgi-bin/SoftCart.exe/JOURNALS/FORENSIC/PAGES/JFS2002083_476.htm%3FE%2Bmystore"></a>. Shuler was not with the team, however, as he had stayed in America due to injury <a href="https%3A//web.archive.org/web/20061018105914/http%3A//ringsidereport.com/rsrboard/viewtopic.php%3Ft%3D1778"></a>. The team was en route to Warsaw, Poland for the USA vs. Poland Box-off as part of "USA vs. the World." event. Among the USA Boxing teammates who were killed in the plane crash were <a href="Lemuel%20Steeples">Lemuel Steeples</a> from St. Louis; Calvin Anderson from Connecticut; <a href="Paul%20Palomino">Paul Palomino</a> - the brother of <a href="Carlos%20Palomino">Carlos Palomino</a> ; <a href="George%20Pimentel">George Pimentel</a>, and Olympic Coach, <a href="Sarge%20Johnson">Sarge Johnson</a>. Members of the team who were also not aboard included <a href="Bobby%20Czyz">Bobby Czyz</a> and <a href="Alex%20Ramos">Alex Ramos</a> <a href="http%3A//www.ikfkickboxing.com/RBF.htm"></a>.
Shuler did not participate in the 1980 Olympics due to the <a href="1980%20Summer%20Olympics%20boycott">boycott</a>. In 2007, he posthumously received one of 461 <a href="List%20of%20Congressional%20Gold%20Medal%20recipients">Congressional Gold Medal</a>s created especially for the spurned athletes.
Highlights.
 <a href="National%20Golden%20Gloves">National Golden Gloves</a> (156 lbs), <a href="Indianapolis%2C%20Indiana">Indianapolis, Indiana</a>, March 1979:
Pan Am Trials (156 lbs), <a href="Toledo%2C%20Ohio">Toledo, Ohio</a>, May–June 1979:
 <a href="Pan%20American%20Games">Pan American Games</a> (156 lbs), <a href="San%20Juan%2C%20Puerto%20Rico">San Juan, Puerto Rico</a>, July 1979:
 <a href="Boxing%20World%20Cup">World Cup</a> (156 lbs), <a href="New%20York%20City">New York City</a>, October 1979:
Frazier–Ali teams match-up (156 lbs) <a href="Houston%2C%20Texas">Houston, Texas</a>, February 1980:
 <a href="National%20Golden%20Gloves">National Golden Gloves</a> (156 lbs), <a href="Hirsch%20Memorial%20Coliseum">Hirsch Memorial Coliseum</a>, <a href="Shreveport%2C%20Louisiana">Shreveport, Louisiana</a>, March 1980:
Olympic Trials (156 lbs), <a href="Atlanta%2C%20Georgia">Atlanta, Georgia</a>, June 1980:
USA–USSR Duals (156 lbs), <a href="Showboat%20Las%20Vegas">Showboat Hotel</a>, <a href="Las%20Vegas%2C%20Nevada">Las Vegas, Nevada</a>, January 1977:
Shuler finished his amateur career with a record of 165–8.
Professional career.
Shuler began his professional boxing career as a middleweight on September 12, 1980 with a second-round knockout of Chris Rogers in Philadelphia. During his five years as a pro, he had 22-1 record with sixteen knockouts. His first and only professional loss came on March 10, 1986 to <a href="Thomas%20Hearns">Thomas Hearns</a> when he was knocked out in the first round.
Death.
Shuler died in a motorcycle accident in Philadelphia on 17 March 1986, just a week after his last fight.
Memory and tribute.
<a href="Bob%20Arum">Bob Arum</a>, the promoter of Shuler's last fight, said that the boxer came to Arum's room a day after the Hearns fight and thanked him for promoting it. Arum, who had promoted many bouts, said that Shuler was the only fighter who had ever done that, adding, "He was a decent, decent young man."
In 1995, his close friend <a href="Percy%20Custus">Percy Custus</a> opened the 'James Shuler Memorial Boxing Gym' in Shuler's native Philadelphia in honor of the fallen fighter. Custus met Shuler in the 1970s at the <a href="Joe%20Frazier">Joe Frazier</a> Gym where they trained together and remained close friends for the rest of James’ life.
